awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for junior researchers to participate in the 7th Coordinating Panel for Advanced Detectors (CPAD) Workshop to be held at Stony Brook University in November, 2022.  The main goal of the workshop is to explore and evaluate detector research & design opportunities, needs, and the challenges ahead for Elementary Particle Physics (EPP) in the US within the context of the Particle Physics Project Prioritization Panel Plan.  The Particle Physics Project Prioritization Panel is a scientific advisory panel tasked with recommending plans for U.S. involvement in particle physics research.   The workshop will also have topical discussions for instrumentation needs for the upcoming Electron Ion Collider to be constructed at the Brookhaven National Lab in the vicinity of Stony Brook. There will be a variety of synergistic topics that concern both fields of physics, EPP and Nuclear Physics in a similar matter.  Involving junior researchers in this workshop will provide an opportunity for them to learn about state-of-the art instrumentation and train for future careers in STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Coordinating Panel for Advanced Detectors (CPAD) is seeking to promote, coordinate and assist in the research and development of instrumentation and detectors for high energy physics experiments. CPAD?s representatives come from the national high-energy physics laboratories and the university community.

The CPAD 2022 workshop was hosted by Stony Brook University (SBU) and was conducted between November 01 and November 04 in 2022. The venue of the workshop took place in the Charles B. Wang Center at SBU.

The event brought together experts and novices in the field of High-Energy/Nuclear Physics (HEP/NP) instrumentation. The scope of the workshop was to discuss state-of-the-art instrumentation and talk about strategies to further improve and implement it in present and/or future apparatuses. It was in continuation to identify the needs in the five science drivers identified by P5 within the twenty-year science vision. The Particle Physics Project Prioritization Panel (P5) is a scientific advisory panel tasked with recommending plans for U.S. investment in particle physics research.

The workshop explored and evaluated Detector R&D opportunities, needs, and the challenges ahead for High Energy Physics in the US within the context of the P5 plan. It provided a platform to integrate junior researchers ? students and postgraduates ? and learn about state-of-the-art instrumentation and therefore train future generations in this field.

The workshop also, for the first time, provided a synergy between the fields of HEP and NP as they are using the same technologies for performing their measurements.

The support awarded by NSF was used for travel support travel for early career researchers who attended the workshop.

The workshop was a success and was highlighted in the monthly newsletter of the APS-DPF.
